titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Eric Breitenbach Photographs of Florida, 1987-1989 RL.11361
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-01 16:13:48 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Collection consists of eight black-and-white photographic prints, most of which were taken as part of Breitenbach's work for his Florida Documentary Project, and two copies of the project's exhibit catalog. The gelatin silver prints measure 14 1/8 x 16 7/8 inches, and are almost all portraits of the many types of people living in Florida and the recreation they enjoy or the significant objects and other people in their lives. Individuals include teenagers, college students, deer hunters, Haitian families and other immigrants; and retirees. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.
did.physdesc: 8 photographic prints; 2 copies of printed catalog

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eric Breitenbach received an M.S. in Instructional Technology and a B.F.A. in Photography from the Rochester Institute of Technology. He is a Senior Faculty member of Daytona State College in Florica, where he has worked since 1981. His photographs have been published in The New York Times Magazine, Newsweek, and Doubletake, and have been widely exhibited. He has also produced documentaries for National Geographic, Sundance Channel, and PBS.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial purposes.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Eric Breitenbach photographs of Florida were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1992.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Eric Breitenbach photographs of Florida, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

archref.unittitle: Gary Monroe photographs [of Haitian immigrants in Florida], 1980-1998,

processinfo.p: Processed and encoded by Paula Jeannet, January 2017.
Accession(s) represented in this finding aid: 1992-0055.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of eight black-and-white photographic prints, most of which were taken as part of Breitenbach's work for his Florida Documentary Project, and two copies of the project's exhibit catalog. The gelatin silver prints measure 14 1/8 x 16 7/8 inches, and are almost all portraits of the many types of people living in Florida and the recreation they enjoy or the significant objects and other people in their lives. Individuals include teenagers, college students, deer hunters, Haitian families and other immigrants; and retirees. The prints are all signed, with title, location, and date written on the backs. The catalog includes reproductions of project photographs, with image titles, locations, and dates; a list of planned exhibits; and a summary and timeline of the project. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

did.unittitle: Two signed copies of Florida Documentary Project catalog, 1989
